Description:
Youth Employment in the Mediterranean (YEM) is a 3-year regional initiative led by UNESCO and funded by the EU. It aims to support youth employment amidst the often-volatile political and socio-economic situation prevalent in many countries of the Mediterranean region. The YEM intervention targets eight countries in the Southern Neighbourhood Region of the European Union, namely Algeria, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Libya, Morocco, Palestine and Tunisia. 
In Jordan, the tourism sector was identified as the priority sector around which the national-level activities will be implemented. The project focuses on promoting TVET as a quality and attractive option, especially for young women, with a focus on work-based learning, entrepreneurship and digital skills. Jordan will also benefit from the establishment of a regional cooperation platform.

Upcoming activities in Jordan:
• Strengthen capacities of the national stakeholders in reinforcing synergies across skills needs assessment tools and developing user-friendly priority sector profiles and YEM skills panoramas for various target audiences
• Conduct the mapping on digital skills mainstreaming and entrepreneurial skills 
• Participate to the sub-regional event on digital skills and regional events, including a capacity building dimension targeted at key stakeholders
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Labor, Technical Colleges, Tourism Sector Skills Council, VTC

SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth

2023 Narrative: All UNHCR’s targets were achieved in line with MEHE 5 years plan and in coordination with the sector. Persistent barriers to refugees’ education, included transportation fees, a lack of school materials, and administrative constraints, continue to hinder access to quality education. Documentation issues pose a significant hurdle at the tertiary level. Furthermore, the security unrest and crises in the south, beginning in the last quarter of 2023, have further exacerbated challenges, particularly BLN and retention programmes in displacement situations. In addition to the number of children benefitting from remedial and retention. UNHCR next to UNICEF and WFP took part in the summer school program 2023 led by MEHE to compensate for learning losses. 22 certified short vocational trainings were market and competency based developed and delivered to an equal number of vulnerable lebanese and refugee out of learning youth.
